close_symbols: struct MHD_PostProcessor (full definition, including fields: buffer_size, buffer_pos, skip_rn, dash_state, state, boundary, blen, nested_boundary, nlen, content_type, content_name, content_filename, content_transfer_encoding, have, must_ikvi, value_offset, have etc.)

enum/defines for PP_* states (PP_Error, PP_Done, PP_Init, PP_NextBoundary, PP_ProcessEntryHeaders, PP_PerformCheckMultipart, PP_ProcessValueToBoundary, PP_PerformCleanup, PP_Nested_Init, PP_Nested_PerformMarking, PP_Nested_ProcessEntryHeaders, PP_Nested_ProcessValueToBoundary, PP_Nested_PerformCleanup, PP_ProcessKey, PP_ProcessValue, PP_Callback)
enum/defines for RN_* values (RN_Inactive, RN_OptN, RN_Dash, RN_Dash2, RN_Full)
NE_* flags (NE_none, NE_content_name, NE_content_type, NE_content_filename, NE_content_transfer_encoding)
enum MHD_Result and constants MHD_YES, MHD_NO
Standard library functions used: memcpy, memmove, strdup, strlen, strstr, free (declarations / standard semantics)
explanation:
For checking the MISRA C for-loop well-formedness rule we must know whether any for-loop behaviour reachable from post_process_multipart (including called functions) modifies loop counters or other objects used as loop counters in a for statement in that scope. Although post_process_multipart itself contains no for statement, MISRA requires examining the behaviour of functions called inside loop bodies as well. Therefore the following are required: 

- struct MHD_PostProcessor (full definition and all fields used): callees may read/modify pp-> fields; if any for-loop in a callee modifies objects that are also used as loop counters in a for in this function, that would matter. Knowing exact fields lets us determine whether any candidate loop counter or loop-control flag (single Boolean identifier) is present and whether callees modify it.

- PP_* state enumerators and RN_* enumerators and NE_* flags: the function manipulates these enums heavily (pp->state, pp->skip_rn, pp->have). To reason about whether a for-loop (in this function or its callees) uses such identifiers as loop counters or loop-control flags and whether they are modified in the body, we need their definitions.

- enum MHD_Result and MHD_YES/MHD_NO: return values used throughout; needed only to understand control flow and early returns when checking loops inside callees.

- find_boundary, process_multipart_headers, process_value_to_boundary, free_unmarked (declarations + bodies): these are direct callees invoked inside loops/loop-like constructs in this function. Any for-loops inside their bodies (or modifications they make to pp or local variables of the caller) must be inspected to ensure they do not break MISRA constraints (e.g., modify the loop counter or other objects forbidden in the for-clause). Provide full definitions so the analyzer can detect any for statements and their effects.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_ and its helper charsequalcaseless: called directly here (and transitively). If they contain for-loops that modify global or passed-in objects, that could affect compliance (the rule treats called-function behaviour as part of the loop body). The bodies are needed to verify they do not modify caller loop counters or flags.

- try_get_value and try_match_header: these are called by process_multipart_headers; their bodies are needed so that the transitive call graph is fully analyzable for for-loops and side effects.

- MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ macro: used in string-pointer arithmetic in the function; its semantics matter when reasoning about which objects are passed to callees and whether callees can modify them.

- Standard library functions used (memcpy, memmove, strdup, strlen, strstr, free): include their declarations / well-known semantics. The analyzer must confirm these functions do not contain surprising for-loops that modify caller variables; listing them makes explicit that their behaviour (copying/allocating memory) is benign for MISRA for-loop concerns.

- MHD_PANIC and _() macros: used in the default case; include definitions to fully understand control-flow and any potential side-effects invoked there.

In short: include full definitions/bodies for all direct callees and their helper functions (find_boundary, process_multipart_headers, process_value_to_boundary, free_unmarked, MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_, charsequalcaseless, try_get_value, try_match_header), the complete MHD_PostProcessor type and related enums/macros/constants, plus the standard library functions used. With those symbols the next analyst can determine whether any for-loop (in this function or in the called functions) violates the MISRA for-loop clauses by modifying loop counters or forbidden objects.
